Idiom (Taiwanese Hokkien): sió tshuí-á kah tuā ê hîⁿ
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: A small entity challenging a much larger one
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: A weaker party challenging a stronger one
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Evokes David vs Goliath idea, often used in local political commentary
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Taiwanese H: [sió tsʰuɪ˨˩ a˦ kaʔ tuɑ˧˥ e˧ hĩ˧]
First Example Sentence: I sió tshuí-á kah tuā ê hîⁿ, bô sái tī kong-hôe kap in káng.
Second Example Sentence: Lí m̄-thang hiah hông--ê, hō͘ lâng kóng lí sió tshuí-á kah tuā ê hîⁿ.
Third Example Sentence: Hit ê kongsi sió tshuí-á kah tuā ê hîⁿ, án-ne mā iánn hó bē lâu.

Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Trying to cover up a lie with more lies
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: To use deception to cover up previous deception
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Common in traditional family and moral teachings
First Example Sentence: Lí tāu-tshí beh tsuí, kám m̄ tsai piah--ê siánn-mih?
Second Example Sentence: Tāu-tshí beh tsuí hō͘ sū kap gū ê khì lóng sán.
Third Example Sentence: I tī hō͘-lâng lóng tāu-tshí beh tsuí, bē hō͘ lâng sióng-sin.

Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: Something surprising or unusual comes out
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: From traditional village storytelling involving animals
First Example Sentence: Hit ê tshut-bān sióng kám-á tshut lāi-á, lâng lóng sio--ê.
Second Example Sentence: Góa bē-sái sióng, hit ê lîn-á kám-á tshut lāi-á--ê!
Third Example Sentence: Tī guá lâng tiong i sī kám-á tshut lāi-á, bē hō͘ lâng thiann.

Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: To reveal one's true feelings or intentions
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: To show your real emotions or purpose
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Found in romantic and dramatic folk narratives
First Example Sentence: I kāng-khu tshut thô͘ tō hō͘ guá kóng siánn-mih tsin-tsiú ê.
Second Example Sentence: Bô kāng-khu tshut thô͘, guá bē hō͘ lí thang--ê tshut-bān.
Third Example Sentence: Tī tsí tīng i tsuí tō kāng-khu tshut thô͘, hó chhiú hō͘ guá tsìng.

Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Hopeless case; beyond repair or effort
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: No matter what, it won't work
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Refers to old tools that cannot be fixed
First Example Sentence: Hit ê lâng phah bē tshut só͘, kā i kong mā bô bat--ê.
Second Example Sentence: Guá lóng siūnn sī phah bē tshut só͘, tsò m̄ tī--ah.
Third Example Sentence: I chia̍h phah bē tshut só͘, tsí pái tsin tán-sim.

Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Big and small differences exist within the same group
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: There are disparities even among the similar
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Old proverb comparing siblings or objects from the same batch
First Example Sentence: Tńg-á tē thih-á, mā sī tī chit ê pē lâng chhōe khì bô tshing.
Second Example Sentence: Guá mā sī sió-lâng, tńg-á tē thih-á, kám bē sī tshòng--ê?
Third Example Sentence: I kā guá piáu--ê tńg-á tē thih-á, bô tsiah koh khòaⁿ bē hiah.

Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Causative clause with resultative verb construction
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: To exert effort until breaking point
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: Push someone too hard or overwork
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Common in rural labor settings, used as cautionary phrase
First Example Sentence: Lí bē-thang piah-sái kā khah kah-khí, i sī tsin u-sîn ê lâng.
Second Example Sentence: Tī tōa-gia̍h piah-sái kā khah kah-khí, guá sī tsiaⁿ bē tiàm--ê.
Third Example Sentence: Piah-sái kā khah kah-khí sī m̄ hō͘ iánn tshòng--ê kāng.

Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Someone is flashy or elegant but lacks substance or foundation
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: All appearance, no stability or home
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Critique of superficiality from literature and folk drama
First Example Sentence: Tsúi-bīn bô tī tshù, guá mā bē ài kah hit--ê lâng thang.
Second Example Sentence: Lí chhōe hit ê, mā sī tsuí-bīn bô tī tshù, tsin khòaⁿ bô tio̍h.
Third Example Sentence: I lâu-tshuì kā tsuí-bīn bô tī tshù, bē tīng--ê tshut-bān.

Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: To pretend friendliness with ulterior motives
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Used in folklore involving betrayal or deception
First Example Sentence: Siâu-kháu tsò pêng-iû, guá mā bē hō͘ lí bē hòng--ê.
Second Example Sentence: I tsin siâu-kháu tsò pêng-iû, bē sái tō tīng--ê.
Third Example Sentence: Hit ê lâng siâu-kháu tsò pêng-iû, tsò-sî sī beh lâi sîⁿ.

Idiom (Taiwanese Hokkien): thâu tshut khì, bô tshut ê
Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Contrastive clause with elliptical second phrase
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: Talks a lot but produces nothing
First Example Sentence: I thâu tshut khì, bô tshut ê, guá chia̍h lóng bē sái.
Second Example Sentence: Thâu tshut khì, bô tshut ê sī tōa tāi-piⁿ ê hō͘-lâng.
Third Example Sentence: Guá hó sī tshun-miâ, m̄ hō͘ thâu tshut khì, bô tshut ê lâng kiò.
